page.title: 04ANCIENT SITES IN PRIDDY
page.content: The best known site is called Priddy Nine Barrows, a bronze age burial ground which dates from 1800BC. This is in fact just part of a larger group of barrows but gets its name from the fact that viewed from the Parish church just nine can be seen on the skyline. Priddy Circles are even earlier. Little remains of this late neolithic henge monument but when seen from the air, the crop marked outlines of 3 complete and 1 broken circle are clearly visible. A Roman road, which was used for the transportation of lead from nearby Charterhouse, cuts through the north of the area and the modern road follows its path. Finds from these sites can be found in the museums in Wells and Taunton.
